stems.text: Christian is working as a junior doctor at a GP clinic. He enters the waiting room to collect his next patient and, to his surprise, his uncle has booked in for an appointment. After the consultation, Christian’s uncle asks if he can be bulk billed. Christian is aware that, according to clinic policy, doctors can only bulk bill patients if they are struggling financially. Christian is aware that his uncle is quite affluent. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Christian in this situation?

questions.text: Comply with his uncle’s request
questions.explanation: Christian must comply with clinical policy and, thus, cannot bulk bill his patient

questions.text: Politely inform his uncle that he will be unable to comply with his request due to clinical policy
questions.explanation: It is advisable for Christian to politely inform his uncle about clinical policy, to ensure that he doesn’t break the rules or upset his uncle

questions.text: Tell his uncle that he will be unable to see him as a patient in the future due to a conflict of interest
questions.explanation: While this may help avoid a similar situation in the future, there is nothing in the scenario to suggest that it is against clinical policy to see family members so this response may be an overreaction

questions.text: Ask a senior doctor at the clinic whether he can bulkbill his uncle
questions.explanation: While it is good that Christian is seeking confirmation from a senior doctor, it not appropriate to seek to defy clinical policy in any way

questions.text: Pay for the treatment himself
questions.explanation: While this may help placate his uncle, this response is unnecessary and is not appropriate – as for other patients this cannot be done

stems.text: A medical student, Kyra, is on a clinical placement with a doctor. This doctor seems to interact well with patients and occasionally makes a few light-hearted jokes with them. During a consultation with a patient, Mohammed, the doctor makes what seems to be a racist joke. The patient does not seem to be offended by it. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Kyra in this situation?

questions.text: Calmly interrupt the conversation and tell the doctor that the comments are inappropriate
questions.explanation: This concern should be discussed in private, not in front of the patient (who, didn’t even appear offended by the comment)

questions.text: Politely and privately raise the concern with the doctor afterwards
questions.explanation: If Kyra perceived the comment to be offensive, she has the right to raise it with him in a non-confrontational manner

questions.text: Raise the matter with her supervisor
questions.explanation: It is not appropriate to escalate the issue in such a manner and, if she felt uncomfortable, she should raise it with the supervisor

questions.text: Apologise to the patient for the comment afterwards
questions.explanation: While there are no immediately negative consequences this would bring about, it should be the responsibility of the individual who made the comment to apologise and, additionally, the patient didn’t seem to be offended by the comment

questions.text: Laugh at the joke
questions.explanation: It is highly inappropriate to laugh at the joke if the comment may be racist as this will only reinforce such behaviour in the mind of the doctor and may upset Mohammed

stems.text: Ava and Jett are medical students, and they have an upcoming oral presentation this week. They have chosen the same topics and have agreed to practice their presentations in front of each other. As Ava reads out her second body paragraph, Jett feels a sense of familiarity. He then realises that the exact same paragraph was in an online article that he read while doing research. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Jett in this situation?

questions.text: Ask Ava if she copied the paragraph from the article
questions.explanation: Jett should first consult Ava and obtain further information before deciding how to proceed

questions.text: Don’t say anything as he may be mistaken
questions.explanation: If there is even a chance that plagiarism has occurred, Jett should investigate the matter further

questions.text: Ask Ava if she needs help with her presentation
questions.explanation: While Ava may have had some trouble with her assignment and resorted to plagiarism as a result, the primary concern is whether plagiarism has actually occurred

questions.text: Alert the tutor to the possibility that Ava has plagiarised her presentation
questions.explanation: While it is important to report plagiarism, Jett needs more information before he can proceed further – he doesn’t know for certain whether plagiarism has occurred and whether this is a draft or her actual presentation. As such, he should check with Ava

questions.text: Ask Ava to send through her script so he can use a plagiarism checker
questions.explanation: While this may help Jett to definitively occur whether plagiarism has occurred, Ava has no obligation to send her script to him – as she may be concerned that Jett could use parts of her speech in his presentation

stems.text: Caleb is a medical student, and he has been asked to vaccinate a patient. The patient is evidently scared of needles and appears to be visibly shaking. When Caleb introduces himself as a medical student, the patient appears even more shocked and worried. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Caleb in this situation? Assume all responses would be said sensitively and politely.

questions.text: I’ve done this many times before, don’t worry
questions.explanation: While this may be appropriate in addressing the patient’s concerns, it isn’t directly addressing their concerns and consent should be obtained first

questions.text: Would you prefer if I ask the doctor to take your blood?
questions.explanation: Caleb has been asked to vaccinate the patient and it isn’t ideal to simply assume that the patient would be uncomfortable with him doing so – the patient’s concerns should be explored in more detail

questions.text: You seem a bit nervous. Are you ok?
questions.explanation: This is very appropriate as it will provide patient with an opportunity to express their concerns, so that they can then be resolved

questions.text: As medical students, we are just as qualified as other doctors
questions.explanation: This response does not properly address the patient’s concerns and isn’t actually true – medical students are doctors in training

questions.text: Ok I’ll quickly give this injection and it’ll be done in no time
questions.explanation: While telling the patient that it will be over quickly may help relax the patient, Caleb shouldn’t rush into the treatment – he should get the patient’s thoughts first

stems.text: Emma is a junior doctor and has to stitch up a relatively large abrasion on a patient’s leg. Emma hasn’t sewn up an abrasion that big before and is quite nervous about doing so. After conducting the first stitch, she believes that it is not in the right area (as the patient moved slightly) and that she should redo it. Redoing the stitch is perfectly safe but may cause the patient to experience a bit more pain. The patient appears anxious too. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Emma in this situation?

questions.text: Explain to the patient what has happened and reassure him that there is no harm done
questions.explanation: Given the nervousness displayed by the patient and the importance of open communication, it is very appropriate for Emma to explain and reassure him

questions.text: Tell the patient to calm down and that she has to redo the stitch because he moved
questions.explanation: Telling the patient to calm down is counterproductive as he is already anxious and medical professionals should never impart blame or judgement on their patients

questions.text: Politely ask the patient to try to remain still if possible
questions.explanation: Without imparting blame or judgement, it is highly appropriate for Emma to communicate politely what is required of the patient to avoid any further setbacks

questions.text: Apologise to the patient for the setback
questions.explanation: If a mistake has been made or a procedure has been delayed in any way, it is definitely appropriate for the doctor to apologise for the inconvenience

questions.text: Report the error as the hospital requires all errors, even minor errors, to be reported
questions.explanation: It is important for Emma to acknowledge, not hide behind, the error and follow hospital policy

stems.text: Blake and Jackson are medical students in the same cohort – and good friends. Blake has recently sat the end of semester test. Jackson, who was sick for much of the semester, has been granted a deferment on the test. Jackson approached Blake and asks if he can help him out with his test preparation. He specifically asks Blake to tell him what questions popped up on the test. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Blake in this situation?

questions.text: Help Jackson with his preparation and provide him access to his notes – but not tell him the questions on the test
questions.explanation: This is very appropriate as Blake will be able to help Jackson with his preparation without engaging in academic misconduct

questions.text: Encourage Jackson to ask the academic tutor for help in his preparation
questions.explanation: Jackson will be able to get the correct advice from the tutor, and this will ensure that he doesn’t receive any unfair advantage

questions.text: Agree to Jackson’s request as he has been sick for much of the semester
questions.explanation: It is entirely inappropriate for Blake to divulge the contents of the test – regardless of Jackson’s situation

questions.text: Not help out Jackson or agree to his request
questions.explanation: While Blake cannot agree to Jackson’s request, he can still help Jackson out with his preparation

questions.text: Ask Jackson to pass on his request to another student as he doesn’t want to get in trouble
questions.explanation: Blake should not encourage Jackson to request this from another student – he must remind him that this is not honourable academic conduct

stems.text: Chloe and Clara are conducting an upper limb examination on a patient, Janice. Chloe examines Janice’s shoulder and concludes that her shoulder is not injured. Clara performs the examination afterwards and believes that Janice’s shoulder is damaged and inflamed. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Clara in this situation?

questions.text: With Janice’s consent, explain to Chloe where she believes the damage is
questions.explanation: Janice is aware that the Chloe and Clara are medical students, and if she is thus ok with them re-examining, it could be a valuable learning experience for both students

questions.text: Ask the supervising doctor to check
questions.explanation: The supervisor can confirm which student is correct and highlight the correct technique to conduct the examination

questions.text: Tell Chloe that she is incorrect
questions.explanation: This is very inappropriate thing to do without knowing who is correct. Not only might this be misleading, but it may hurt Chloe’s self-esteem and embarrass her in front of the patient

questions.text: Apologise to the patient and ask if they can both re-examine
questions.explanation: It is important to seek permission from the patient and, subsequently, the students can consult with each other and re-examine the shoulder as necessary

questions.text: Take Chloe’s word for it as she is known to be very intelligent
questions.explanation: Regardless of reputations and intelligence, Clara should pursue this further and seek to clarify the examination process – with Chloe and even the supervisor perhaps

stems.text: Devon, a medical student, has been under a lot of stress recently. His mother, who is a single parent, has recently become sick and he must look after his younger siblings. At a clinical placement, it is evident that Devon is tired and withdrawn and his supervisor picks up on this. He complains about Devon’s lack of enthusiasm and states that he will have to mark him down and provide negative feedback if this continues. Leah, another student, is in the room when this happens and is aware of Devon’s situation. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Leah in this situation?

questions.text: Speak up on Devon’s behalf and mention that he has been having issues at home
questions.explanation: Whilst there are reasons for his behaviour, Devon’s actions are inappropriate and fairly picked up on by the supervisor. Additionally, Leah should respect Devon’s privacy as he may not wish to divulge this to this supervisor

questions.text: Not interfere at all
questions.explanation: Remaining silent is appropriate as Devon’s actions are inappropriate and fairly picked up on by the supervisor and Leah should respect Devon’s privacy. However, she should raise the matter in private with Devon

questions.text: Tell the supervisor to be more empathetic of Devon
questions.explanation: Leah is not in a position to make demands to the supervisor and the supervisor is most likely unaware of Devon’s situation; this comment is inflammatory and unnecessary

questions.text: Ask Devon if he needs any help or support
questions.explanation: Devon is evidently under pressure and having a difficult time, as such Leah should reach out to him to see if he needs any assistance

questions.text: Advise Devon to discuss this matter with his academic advisor
questions.explanation: While it is definitely appropriate for Devon to discuss his difficulties with his advisor, this does not address the immediate situation with the supervisor that Devon finds himself in

stems.text: Mason is a junior doctor working in a rural hospital and a patient is rushed in at short notice during Mason’s break. During this break, Mason was expected to meet with his supervisor. However, this patient is in an urgent condition and needs immediate treatment. There are no other doctors available. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Mason?

questions.text: Proceed to the meeting as it is his break, and he has no obligation to see the patient
questions.explanation: This patient urgently needs treatment and there are no other doctors available, this must take priority over Mason’s break and his meeting

questions.text: Ask the nurse to keep the patient stable while he attends the meeting
questions.explanation: While not as bad as simply not seeing the patient, this patient urgently needs treatment and may not be able to be kept stable and, hence, Mason should not attend the meeting

questions.text: Tend to the patient
questions.explanation: This patient urgently needs treatment the other doctors are not available; hence, Mason should see this patient

questions.text: Let the supervisor know you won’t be able to attend the meeting
questions.explanation: Providing that time permits this, Mason should let the supervisor know that he will not be able to attend. If the patient is in an urgent condition, this may not be possible

questions.text: Take a few minutes to calm down and come up with a reasonable course of action
questions.explanation: While it is important to be calm and measured in approach, the patient is in urgent need of care so there likely isn’t time to do this

stems.text: You are a GP. A patient is becoming irate and complains that the medical student, whom you are supervising, is being rude and threatening. This patient is notoriously difficult and, from your experience with them, the medical student is both polite and friendly. How appropriate are each of the following responses for you to take in this scenario?

questions.text: Dismiss the patient’s concerns
questions.explanation: Patient concerns should never be dismissed – they must be explored further

questions.text: Apologise to the patient for the medical student’s behaviour
questions.explanation: While this may help diffuse the situation, apologising on behalf of the student is inappropriate as you don’t actually know whether the student has done anything wrong

questions.text: Investigate the patient’s concerns further
questions.explanation: Patient concerns should never be dismissed – they must be explored further

questions.text: Tell the patient, politely, to calm down
questions.explanation: This response is counterproductive and will likely only function to anger the patient further

questions.text: Privately ask the medical student for their perspective on the issue
questions.explanation: Before proceeding further, it is important to gather more information and hear both sides of the story
